title: Mass-to-light ratio
text:
In <a href="astrophysics">astrophysics</a> and <a href="physical%20cosmology">physical cosmology</a> the mass-to-light ratio, normally designated with the Greek letter <a href="upsilon">upsilon</a>, , is the quotient between the total <a href="mass">mass</a> of a <a href="spatial%20volume">spatial volume</a> (typically on the scales of a <a href="galaxy">galaxy</a> or a <a href="galaxy%20cluster">cluster</a>) and its <a href="luminosity">luminosity</a>. These ratios are often reported using the value calculated for the <a href="Sun">Sun</a> as a baseline ratio which is a constant  = 5133 <a href="kilogram">kg</a>/<a href="Watt">W</a>: equal to the <a href="solar%20mass">solar mass</a> divided by the <a href="solar%20luminosity">solar luminosity</a> , . The mass-to-light ratios of galaxies and clusters are all much greater than due in part to the fact that most of the <a href="matter">matter</a> in these objects does not reside within stars and observations suggest that a large fraction is present in the form of <a href="dark%20matter">dark matter</a>.
Luminosities are obtained from <a href="photometry%20%28astronomy%29">photometric</a> observations, correcting the observed <a href="brightness">brightness</a> of the object for the <a href="cosmic%20distance%20ladder">distance dimming</a> and <a href="interstellar%20extinction">extinction</a> effects. In general, unless a complete <a href="electromagnetic%20spectrum">spectrum</a> of the <a href="Electromagnetic%20radiation">radiation</a> emitted by the object is obtained, a model must be extrapolated through either <a href="power%20law">power law</a> or <a href="blackbody">blackbody</a> fits. The luminosity thus obtained is known as the <a href="bolometric%20luminosity">bolometric luminosity</a>.
Masses are often calculated from the dynamics of the <a href="virial%20theorem">virialized system</a> or from <a href="gravitational%20lens">gravitational lens</a>ing. Typical mass-to-light ratios for galaxies range from 2 to 10  while on the largest scales, the mass to light ratio of the <a href="observable%20universe">observable universe</a> is approximately 100 , in concordance with the <a href="Lambda-CDM%20model">current best fit cosmological model</a>.
